     124             :     /*
     125             :      * For telemetry, we want to keep a fixed max bucket size over time so we
     126             :      * don't have to switch histograms. 100 is conservative; as of this writing

     130             :     NUM_TELEMETRY_REASONS = 100

     139             : } /* namespace gcreason */
     140             : 
     141             : /*
     142             :  * Zone GC:
     143             :  *
     144             :  * SpiderMonkey's GC is capable of performing a collection on an arbitrary
     145             :  * subset of the zones in the system. This allows an embedding to minimize
     146             :  * collection time by only collecting zones that have run code recently,
     147             :  * ignoring the parts of the heap that are unlikely to have changed.
     148             :  *
     149             :  * When triggering a GC using one of the functions below, it is first necessary
     150             :  * to select the zones to be collected. To do this, you can call
     151             :  * PrepareZoneForGC on each zone, or you can call PrepareForFullGC to select
     152             :  * all zones. Failing to select any zone is an error.
     153             :  */
     154             : 
     155             : /**
     156             :  * Schedule the given zone to be collected as part of the next GC.
     157             :  */
     158             : extern JS_PUBLIC_API(void)
     159             : PrepareZoneForGC(Zone* zone);
     160             : 
     161             : /**
     162             :  * Schedule all zones to be collected in the next GC.
     163             :  */
     164             : extern JS_PUBLIC_API(void)
     165             : PrepareForFullGC(JSContext* cx);
     166             : 
     167             : /**
     168             :  * When performing an incremental GC, the zones that were selected for the
     169             :  * previous incremental slice must be selected in subsequent slices as well.
     170             :  * This function selects those slices automatically.
     171             :  */
     172             : extern JS_PUBLIC_API(void)
     173             : PrepareForIncrementalGC(JSContext* cx);
     174             : 
     175             : /**
     176             :  * Returns true if any zone in the system has been scheduled for GC with one of
     177             :  * the functions above or by the JS engine.
     178             :  */
     179             : extern JS_PUBLIC_API(bool)
     180             : IsGCScheduled(JSContext* cx);
     181             : 
     182             : /**
     183             :  * Undoes the effect of the Prepare methods above. The given zone will not be
     184             :  * collected in the next GC.
     185             :  */
     186             : extern JS_PUBLIC_API(void)
     187             : SkipZoneForGC(Zone* zone);
     188             : 
     189             : /*
     190             :  * Non-Incremental GC:
     191             :  *
     192             :  * The following functions perform a non-incremental GC.
     193             :  */
     194             : 
     195             : /**
     196             :  * Performs a non-incremental collection of all selected zones.
     197             :  *
     198             :  * If the gckind argument is GC_NORMAL, then some objects that are unreachable
     199             :  * from the program may still be alive afterwards because of internal
     200             :  * references; if GC_SHRINK is passed then caches and other temporary references
     201             :  * to objects will be cleared and all unreferenced objects will be removed from
     202             :  * the system.
     203             :  */
     204             : extern JS_PUBLIC_API(void)
     205             : GCForReason(JSContext* cx, JSGCInvocationKind gckind, gcreason::Reason reason);
     206             : 
     207             : /*
     208             :  * Incremental GC:
     209             :  *
     210             :  * Incremental GC divides the full mark-and-sweep collection into multiple
     211             :  * slices, allowing client JavaScript code to run between each slice. This
     212             :  * allows interactive apps to avoid long collection pauses. Incremental GC does
     213             :  * not make collection take less time, it merely spreads that time out so that
     214             :  * the pauses are less noticable.
     215             :  *
     216             :  * For a collection to be carried out incrementally the following conditions
     217             :  * must be met:
     218             :  *  - The collection must be run by calling JS::IncrementalGC() rather than
     219             :  *    JS_GC().
     220             :  *  - The GC mode must have been set to JSGC_MODE_INCREMENTAL with
     221             :  *    JS_SetGCParameter().
     222             :  *
     223             :  * Note: Even if incremental GC is enabled and working correctly,
     224             :  *       non-incremental collections can still happen when low on memory.
     225             :  */
     226             : 
     227             : /**
     228             :  * Begin an incremental collection and perform one slice worth of work. When
     229             :  * this function returns, the collection may not be complete.
     230             :  * IncrementalGCSlice() must be called repeatedly until
     231             :  * !IsIncrementalGCInProgress(cx).
     232             :  *
     233             :  * Note: SpiderMonkey's GC is not realtime. Slices in practice may be longer or
     234             :  *       shorter than the requested interval.
     235             :  */
     236             : extern JS_PUBLIC_API(void)
     237             : StartIncrementalGC(JSContext* cx, JSGCInvocationKind gckind, gcreason::Reason reason,
     238             :                    int64_t millis = 0);
     239             : 
     240             : /**
     241             :  * Perform a slice of an ongoing incremental collection. When this function
     242             :  * returns, the collection may not be complete. It must be called repeatedly
     243             :  * until !IsIncrementalGCInProgress(cx).
     244             :  *
     245             :  * Note: SpiderMonkey's GC is not realtime. Slices in practice may be longer or
     246             :  *       shorter than the requested interval.
     247             :  */
     248             : extern JS_PUBLIC_API(void)
     249             : IncrementalGCSlice(JSContext* cx, gcreason::Reason reason, int64_t millis = 0);
     250             : 
     251             : /**
     252             :  * If IsIncrementalGCInProgress(cx), this call finishes the ongoing collection
     253             :  * by performing an arbitrarily long slice. If !IsIncrementalGCInProgress(cx),
     254             :  * this is equivalent to GCForReason. When this function returns,
     255             :  * IsIncrementalGCInProgress(cx) will always be false.
     256             :  */
     257             : extern JS_PUBLIC_API(void)
     258             : FinishIncrementalGC(JSContext* cx, gcreason::Reason reason);
     259             : 
     260             : /**
     261             :  * If IsIncrementalGCInProgress(cx), this call aborts the ongoing collection and
     262             :  * performs whatever work needs to be done to return the collector to its idle
     263             :  * state. This may take an arbitrarily long time. When this function returns,
     264             :  * IsIncrementalGCInProgress(cx) will always be false.
     265             :  */
     266             : extern JS_PUBLIC_API(void)
     267             : AbortIncrementalGC(JSContext* cx);

     319             : enum GCProgress {
     320             :     /*
     321             :      * During non-incremental GC, the GC is bracketed by JSGC_CYCLE_BEGIN/END
     322             :      * callbacks. During an incremental GC, the sequence of callbacks is as
     323             :      * follows:
     324             :      *   JSGC_CYCLE_BEGIN, JSGC_SLICE_END  (first slice)
     325             :      *   JSGC_SLICE_BEGIN, JSGC_SLICE_END  (second slice)
     326             :      *   ...
     327             :      *   JSGC_SLICE_BEGIN, JSGC_CYCLE_END  (last slice)
     328             :      */
     329             : 
     330             :     GC_CYCLE_BEGIN,
     331             :     GC_SLICE_BEGIN,
     332             :     GC_SLICE_END,
     333             :     GC_CYCLE_END
     334             : };

     554             : /**

     556             :  * any allocation that could potentially trigger a GC occurs while this guard
     557             :  * object is live. This is most useful to help the exact rooting hazard analysis
     558             :  * in complex regions, since it cannot understand dataflow.
     559             :  *
     560             :  * Note: GC behavior is unpredictable even when deterministic and is generally
     561             :  *       non-deterministic in practice. The fact that this guard has not
     562             :  *       asserted is not a guarantee that a GC cannot happen in the guarded
     563             :  *       region. As a rule, anyone performing a GC unsafe action should
     564             :  *       understand the GC properties of all code in that region and ensure
     565             :  *       that the hazard analysis is correct for that code, rather than relying
     566             :  *       on this class.
     567             :  */
     568             : class JS_PUBLIC_API(AutoSuppressGCAnalysis) : public AutoAssertNoAlloc
     569             : {
     570             :   public:
     571             :     AutoSuppressGCAnalysis() : AutoAssertNoAlloc() {}
     572             :     explicit AutoSuppressGCAnalysis(JSContext* cx) : AutoAssertNoAlloc(cx) {}
     573             : } JS_HAZ_GC_SUPPRESSED;

     589             : /**
     590             :  * Place AutoCheckCannotGC in scopes that you believe can never GC. These
     591             :  * annotations will be verified both dynamically via AutoAssertNoGC, and
     592             :  * statically with the rooting hazard analysis (implemented by making the
     593             :  * analysis consider AutoCheckCannotGC to be a GC pointer, and therefore
